name: gc_autopet
title: AutoPET challenge winner: False Positive Reduction Network

summary.description: The task of the AutoPET challenge was algorithm creation for automatic tumor lesion segmentation in whole-body FDG-PET/CT

inputs.label: FDG-PET image
inputs.description: Positron Emission Tomography (PET) image with fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) tracer

inputs.label: CT image
inputs.description: Computed Tomography (CT) image after contrast administration

outputs.description: Binary tumor lesion segmentation for the input PET/CT images.

details.name: False Positive Reduction Network
details.cite: Y. Peng, J. Kim, D. Feng and L. Bi, 'Automatic Tumor Segmentation via False Positive Reduction Network for Whole-Body Multi-Modal PET/CT Images', In arXiv:2209.07705, doi: 10.48550/arXiv:2209.07705.

publications.title: Automatic Tumor Segmentation via False Positive Reduction Network for Whole-Body Multi-Modal PET/CT Images

use.title: Intended use
use.text: Tumor segmentation for whole-body FDG-PET/CT image pairs.

analyses.title: Evaluation
analyses.text: The DICE score was used for evaluation segmentation performance on an independent private test set of 150 studies for the final ranking.

evaluation.title: Evaluation data
evaluation.text: The final test set consists of a separate private dataset of 150 FDG-PET/CT image pairs

training.title: Training data
training.text: Training data consists of 1014 studies acquired at the University Hospital TÃ¼bingen and is made publicly available on TCIA (as DICOM, NiFTI and HDF5 files).

references.label: A whole-body FDG-PET/CT dataset with manually annotated tumor lesions (FDG-PET-CT-Lesions)

limitations.title: Limitations
limitations.text: This algorithm was developed for research purposes only.
